filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s water color illustrations to the plays of William Shakespeare.
Although less extensive and well known than his illustrations of John Milton’s poems, Blake’s water colors based on Shakespeare’s plays constitute a significant group of designs. The earliest, dating from c. 1779, is probably one of Blake’s illustrations of English history but nonetheless evokes Shakespeare’s King Lear. The series of seven small ovals picturing characters from the plays also dates from Blake’s early years. The concentrated focus on just one or two figures filling most of the pictorial space may be Blake’s response to popular interest in miniature portraiture. The reason for his execution of this group is not known; like the English history designs, they may have been intended for eventual publication as engravings. The series of Shakespeare character portraits by John Hamilton Mortimer, published as engravings in the mid-1770s, may have influenced Blake’s similar project.
Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing is one of Blake’s largest water colors of the 1780s. Its size and quality suggest that it may have been intended for exhibition, like the water colors illustrating the life of Joseph displayed at the Royal Academy in 1785. The circle of dancers and Puck’s stance with arms raised echo similar motifs in George Romney’s Leveson-Gower Family, painted in 1776-77 and published as a mezzotint by John Raphael Smith in 1781.
Blake was clearly attracted to the vision of Queen Katherine in Henry VIII, act 4, scene 2, for he executed four versions beginning c. 1783-90 and concluding with the highly finished and complex water color of c. 1825-26. Blake’s water color of Queen Katherine’s dream dated 1809 is part of a series of six illustrations to Shakespeare’s plays commissioned by Joseph Thomas, the clergyman who had earlier employed Blake to illustrate Milton’s Comus and Paradise Lost. In a letter of 31 July 1801 to William Hayley, John Flaxman added a postscript to Blake, including the following: “he [Thomas] also desired you [Blake] will make two designs in bister or Indian Ink, from Shakespeare’s Troylus & Cressida, Coriolanus, either of the 3 plays of Henry 6.th Richard the 3.d or Henry the 8.th each design for one play for which he will give a Guinea each, the dimensions as follow the paper. an upright square of 12 Inches & half by 8 Inches, within this Space leaving a moderate margin, the principal figure not exceeding 6 Inches high” (Butlin 547). Blake’s designs (most now trimmed) roughly follow these size requirements, necessitated by Thomas’s desire to create an extra-illustrated copy of the 1632 second folio of Shakespeare’s plays, but Blake waited eight years before completing the commission, changed the medium from monochrome drawings to water colors, and illustrated only two plays, Richard III and Henry VIII, specified by Flaxman. Blake may have chosen the other passages for illustration, at some point convincing Thomas of their appropriateness.
Many of Blake’s Shakespeare designs show his predilection for scenes dealing with perceptions that extend beyond the world of the physical senses. The four versions of Queen Katherine’s dream epitomize this lifelong interest in imaginative and visionary experiences. A corollary is Blake’s attraction to representations of the arts, demonstrated by Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing and his portrayal of Pegasus, the classical embodiment of poetic inspiration, in As If an Angel Dropped Down from the Clouds among the designs for Thomas.

provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; sold by Catherine Blake c. 1828-29 to Mrs. Samuel Smith and Julia Smith (see Butlin 53 and Bentley, *Records*, page 484); Julia Smith by 1876, possibly by descent; by descent to Thena Clough; sold Sotheby's, 6 March 1934, lot 337 (£30 to Alice G. E. Carthew); bequeathed by Carthew in 1940 to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection).

desc.objtitle: Lear and Cordelia in Prison test, Object 1 (Butlin 53)

objnote.p: This work is probably part of Blake's series of water colors illustrating English history rather than an illustration of Shakespeare's *King Lear*. Indeed, the scene does not appear in the play, although Blake may be picturing what Lear imagines will happen in his great speech in Act V scene 3 beginning "No, no, no, no! Come, let's away to prison." There Lear and Cordelia will "wear out" their days "in a walled prison." Even if the design is not based directly on Shakespeare's play, his treatment of Lear and his daughters is so culturally powerful that an association of this subject with his play is difficult to avoid. The placement of Lear and Cordelia in prison may have been influenced by Nahum Tate’s adaptation of *King Lear* of 1681. The stage direction to the third scene of Act V places them in "A Prison. Lear asleep, with his head on Cordelia’s lap." An inscription below the drawing on the mat (not shown) reads "Lear and Cordelia (early manner)." An inscription on the back of the mat reads "Bought of Mrs. Blake the first or second year after her husband's death. Price of this and 'the Grave' [Butlin 134] was about £8.8." The longer inscription was probably written by Mrs. Samuel Smith or Julia Smith; another inscription on the back of the mat reads in part "Exhibited at Burlington Fine Arts Club 1876 No. 223 lent by Miss Julia Smith." The catalogue for this exhibition states that the lender was "Miss Julia Smith."

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a room with stone walls that suggests a prison cell, a gowned female figure with long curly hair sits facing right with her head turned down to look toward an older male figure who lies on the ground with his head in her lap. The female figure wraps her bent right arm across her chest and bends her left arm upward near her face. Her legs are bent with both bare feet visible at left. She wears a swath of drapery around her lower body; additional drapery, which she may hold in her right hand, extends out from her torso at right in a serpentine flourish. The male figure, whose eyes appear to be closed, has white hair and a beard. He may be sleeping. He wears a gown or tunic, and blue drapery covers his torso and the floor below him. He raises both bent arms above his head to rest on the female figure’s lap with his left hand touching his right wrist. Both of his legs are bent but extended to the right. The water color probably represents the characters Lear, the King of Britain, and Cordelia, his youngest daughter. This specific scene does not appear in Shakespeare's King Lear, although Blake may be picturing what Lear imagines will happen in his great speech in Act V scene 3 beginning "No, no, no, no! Come, let's away to prison." There Lear and Cordelia will "wear out" their days "in a walled prison." The scene does occur in Nahum Tate’s adaptation of King Lear of 1681 in the stage direction to the third scene of Act V: "Scene, A Prison. Lear asleep, with his head on Cordelia’s lap." This water color is probably one of Blake's illustrations to English history rather than directly related to Shakespeare's King Lear.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female figure with long curly hair sits facing right with her head turned down to look toward an older male figure who lies with his head in her lap. Bending forward slightly, she wraps her bent left arm across her chest and bends her left arm upward near her face, perhaps touching it. She may hold drapery in her left hand. Her legs are bent with both bare feet visible at left. This figure is probably Cordelia, the daughter of Lear, as a prisoner.
The female figure wears a swath of drapery around her lower body; additional drapery, which she may hold in her right hand, extends out from her torso at right in a serpentine flourish.

A male figure lies on the ground facing forward with his head resting on the lap of the female figure at left. He has short white hair and a beard; his eyes appear to be closed, suggesting he is sleeping. He wears a gown or tunic with long sleeves, and blue drapery covers his torso and the floor below him. Both arms are bent and raised above his head to rest on the female figure’s lap with his left hand touching his right wrist. Both of his legs are bent but extended to the right. This figure is probably Lear, the King of Britain, as a prisoner.
The two figures in this scene occupy what appears to be a square interior room with a floor and walls made of stone. It may represent a prison cell.
Dark shadows are visible in the lower left and upper right corners of the room.
